document.docTitle: Insights on the antiradical capacity and mechanism of phytocannabinoids: H-abstraction and electron transfer processes in physiological media and the influence of the acid-base equilibrium

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Insights on the antiradical capacity and mechanism of phytocannabinoids: H-abstraction and electron transfer processes in physiological media and the influence of the acid-base equilibrium

paragraph.docTitle: Insights on the antiradical capacity and mechanism of phytocannabinoids: H-abstraction and electron transfer processes in physiological media and the influence of the acid-base equilibrium

paragraph.emphasis: Chemistry Department, Faculty of Exact Science, University of Constantine 1, Constantine , 25000, Algeria

document.paragraph: A R T I C L E I N F O

subSection.paragraph: Phytocannabinoids
DFT calculations
Antioxidant activity
Kinetic study
A B S T R A C T

Phytocannabinoids are natural products primarily isolated from
Cannabis sativa
that exhibit the typical C21 terpenophenolic skeleton. This class of compounds has been shown to be effective in the treatment of various oxidation-related diseases, which has made their antioxidant properties the focus of increasing interest. In the present contribution, the primary antioxidant properties of eight representative phytocannabinoids have been systematically studied against a variety of biologically significant radical species using the density functional theory (DFT) method. The findings demonstrated that phytocannabinoids, in water at physiological pH, exhibit excellent radical scavenging capacity, mainly exerted by the single electron transfer (SET) process from the deprotonated state. In contrast, phytocannabinoids are moderate radical scavengers in non-polar environment via the formal hydrogen atom transfer (fHAT) process. Among the compounds examined, cannabichromene (CBC) and cannabifuran (CBF) had the greatest free radical scavenging capacity in water, surpassing even common antioxidants like BHT and Trolox. CBF is expected to have potent antiradical action toward peroxyl radicals, alkoxy radicals, and nitrogen dioxide in water at physiological pH. These results provide supporting evidence that phytocannabinoids may be useful in scavenging harmful free radicals in physiological environments.

Following the discovery in 1964 of 9-tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) as the active molecule of the herbaceous plant
Cannabis sativa L. (Cannabaceae)
( Gaoni and Mechoulam, 1964 ), research has continued to understand this plant with surprising effects, at times psychotropic, but with an increasing number of studies demonstrating a significant therapeutic potential ( Aliferis and Bernard-Perron, 2020 ). Despite a large number of synonyms
C. sativa
is now considered the sole species of the Cannabis genus but is divided into several phenotypes known as sub-species and varieties ( Chandra et al., 2017 ).
C. sativa
has a wide range of chemical compounds, including cannabinoids, terpenoids, and flavonoids. All of these compounds are found in the fatty resin that develops in the trichomes of female plants ( Rock and Parker, 2021 ).
C. sativa
contains about 100 cannabinoids, including the most well-known THC, cannabidiol (CBD), cannabinol (CBN), cannabichromene (CBC), cannabig´erol (CBG), cannabinodiol (CBND), cannabielsoin (CBE), cannabicyclol (CBL), and cannabitriol (CBT) ( Rock and Parker, 2021 ). In spite of having a common molecular framework (the C21 terpenophenolic skeleton), these compounds with widely varying chemical structures exhibit a wide range of different characteristics. THC is the most potent psychoactive compound, whereas CBD has no psychoactive effects but does have anti-inflammatory properties ( Esposito et al., 2013 ). The activities of phytocannabinoids with no psychotropic effects are now being researched since they are potentially therapeutic molecules ( Franco et al., 2020 ; Klein, 2005 ). Several cannabinoid-derived medications have already been approved, including DRONABINOL, a THC-synthesized drug used in the prevention or treatment of nausea and vomiting caused by chemotherapy, EPIDYOLEX, a CBD synthesized drug recently approved for the treatment of epilepsy crises, and SATIVEX, a
C. sativa
extract containing THC and CBD with defined concentrations developed for the treatment of plaque sclerosis ( Franco et al., 2020 ).
E-mail address: boulebd.houssem@umc.edu.dz.

Frontier molecular orbitals (FMOs) i.e., HOMO (highest occupied molecular orbital) and LUMO (lowest unoccupied molecular orbital) are useful tools for describing the scavenging activity of organic compounds. The distribution and energy of these orbitals can provide information about the sites of free radical attack as well as the overall ability of the molecule to act as an electron acceptor or donor. The FMOs of the phytocannabinoids studied are presented in Fig. 2 . From the obtained findings, it is clear that HOMOs and LUMOs are mainly located on the phenolic moieties of all compounds. This suggests that the OH groups of phytocannabinoids play a crucial role in determining their reactivity.

The energy of HOMO reflects the ability of the molecule to lose an electron. The results show that the HOMO energy of phytocannabinoids decreases in the following order CBE (6.20 eV) > CBC (6.98 eV) > CBN (6.99 eV) > CBND (7.05 eV) > CBF (7.07 eV) > TCBN (7.15 eV) > CBG (7.33 eV). This indicates that CBE, CBC, and CBN are the strongest electron donors, while TCBN and CBG are the weakest. Moreover, CBE (ΔE = 6.01 eV), CBC (ΔE = 6.74 eV), and CBN (ΔE = 6.74 eV) show a significantly small energy gap compared to that of CBG (7.10 eV), implying that these molecules are the most potent in terms of electron donating.

To investigate antiradical activity in water, it is necessary to understand acid-base equilibrium under physiological conditions (pH = 7.4). Since experimental data on phytocannabinoids are lacking, the relative pKa values were calculated using a procedure described in the literature (Rebollar-Zepeda et al., 2011). The computed values are shown in Fig. 3 , and Fig. S2 depicts the mole fraction as a function of the pH of the neutral and anionic species. The molar fractions have been calculated using the following equations:
10 pKa
%Phyto O – = ) × 100

As per Fig. 3 , it can be seen that the neutral form is prevalent at physiological pH (7.4), with ratios ranging from 99.01% to 99.97% ( Table S2 ). The anionic form, on the other hand, is present in low concentrations ranging from 0.02% to 0.99% ( Table S2 ). The fHAT and RAF mechanisms should be unaffected by this minimum proportion, but it may be critical for the SET process. As a result, the anionic form is investigated in this study for the SET mechanism in water, whereas only the neutral form is investigated for fHAT and RAF mechanisms.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 1. Molecular structure and atomic numbering of the investigated phytocannabinoids.
Fig. 2. Energy and distribution of HOMOs and LUMOs of phytocannabinoids.
Fig. 3. Acid-base equilibrium of phytocannabinoids in water at physiological pH (7.4).

subSection.paragraph: Antioxidants react with free radicals to produce much less reactive species in which the free electron is distributed over the entire molecule and not localized on a single atom. This process can take place according to several mechanisms involving hydrogen transfer (fHAT), electron transfer (SET) or by a non-redox path (RAF) according to the following equations:
Antiox H + R • → Antiox • + RH (fHAT)
Antiox + R • → Antiox +• + R (SET)
Antiox + R • → [Antiox R] • (RAF)

fHAT and RAF involve uncharged species; thus, their feasibility is possible under both polar and lipid conditions. On the other hand, SET involves the transfer of electrons from an anionic or a neutral species leading to a neutral or a cationic radical as follows:
Antiox OH + R • → [Antiox OH] +• + R (SET1)
Antiox O + R • → Antiox O ⋅ + R (SET2)

Phytocannabinoids ( Fig. 1 ) have several potential sites for free radial attack. According to the fHAT mechanism, the phenolic OH groups are the most suitable sites for donating their hydrogen atoms; however, studies on antioxidants have shown that some benzylic hydrogen atoms may also be involved in the hydrogen transfer process. Furthermore, we previously demonstrated that cannabidiolic acid (CBDA) interacts with HOO • in lipid environments via a benzylic group rather than a phenolic OH group ( Boulebd, 2022a ). Thus, in addition to the phenolic OH groups, all potential CH groups were examined in this study. In terms of the RAF mechanism, it is known that the attack of HOO • on the aromatic nucleus is energetically unfavorable since it destroys aromaticity. Only attacks on non-phenolic double bonds are possible. This was also taken into consideration in this study.

Fig. 4 shows the computed Gibbs free energies of the reaction of phytocannabinoids with HOO • following fHAT, RAF, and SET mechanisms in physiological media. As can be seen, in both environments, the phenolic OH groups of all phytocannabinoids show low ΔG values for the fHAT mechanism ranging from 3.1 to 1.9 kcal/mol. This implies that this process is thermodynamically favorable for these OH groups. Similarly, benzylic CH groups, including 3 CH and 12 CH of TCBN and CBG respectively, also showed low ΔG values of 9.9 to 1.2 kcal/mol, reflecting the feasibility of fHAT for these two groups as well. Considering the RAF mechanism, it appears that the reactions at positions C4, C19, C20, and (C17, C18) of CBC, CBND, CBE, and CBG, respectively are exergonic or almost isergonic. Therefore, RAF is a thermodynamically possible mechanism for some phytocannabinoids. Finally, the ΔG values of the SET mechanism are slightly endergonic (0.5 to 4.3 kcal/mol) and indicate that SET is also possible in water.

In the first step, the kinetic study of the reaction of phytocannabinoids with HOO • was performed in the gas phase for all the thermodynamically conceivable pathways and the results obtained are reported in Table S2 . Only, the fHAT and RAF mechanisms were considered since they are relatively slightly dependent on the environments. As we can see, the calculated branching ratios show that fHAT is the dominant process for all phytocannabinoids, while RAF has no contribution to the overall rate constant (Γ = 0%). The 3 CH group of the TCBN has a rate constant of 1.08 × 104 M 1 s 1 which contributes 28% to the k overall . This implies that this CH group may play a role in the primary antioxidant activity of TCBN. On the other hand, that of CBG (12 CH ) has no contribution to the k overall with a rate constant of 2.53 × 10 1 M 1 s 1 (Γ = 0%).

Based on this preliminary assessment in the gas phase, the antiradical activity in the lipid-like environment was modeled following the fHAT mechanism at the phenolic OH groups and the active CH groups. On the other hand, the SET mechanism from the anionic state was also considered in water. The overall rate constants ( k overall ) were calculated as follows:
In the lipid-like environment
k overall = k app(fHAT OH) + k app (fHAT CH )
In water
k overall = k f (fHAT OH) + k f (fHAT CH ) + k f (SET2)

The results are reported in Table 1 , and the localized transition states are shown in Fig. 5 . In the lipid-like environment, the radical scavenging capacity of phytocannabinoids is moderate to good with overall rate coefficients of 6.00 × 10 1 to 8.80 × 10 3 M 1 s 1 . The best candidates were found to be, in order, TCBN, CBG, CBF, and CBC. Their overall rate constants are somewhat close to that of BHT (1.70 × 10 4 M 1 s 1 ) ( Boulebd, 2022b ) suggesting that these molecules are good antioxidants under lipid physiological conditions. Analysis of the branching ratios reveals that the CH group of TCBN plays a significant role in the overall reactivity of the molecule with a contribution of 35% to the overall rate constant. This highlights the potential role of benzylic CH groups in antioxidant action. Similar outcomes were also attained in our earlier work on CBDA ( Boulebd, 2022a ).

caption.paragraph: Fig. 4. Gibbs free energies of the HOO • scavenging reaction of phytocannabinoids under physiological conditions.
Kinetic data of the reaction of phytocannabinoids with HOO • in physiological media at M06–2X/6–311++ G (d,p) level: activation Gibbs free energies (ΔG = in kcal/
mol), tunneling corrections (κ), rate constants ( k in M 1 s 1 ), and branching ratios (Γ in %).

subSection.paragraph: f app

On the other hand, the antiradical activity of phytocannabinoids under physiological polar conditions appears to be substantially better with overall rate coefficients ranging from 5.20 × 104 to 5.25 × 106 M 1 s 1 . CBN, CBC, and CBF are the most promising molecules with rate coefficients of the order of 106 M 1 s 1 . The SET mechanism from the anionic states is dominant or almost exclusive for all phytocannabinoids. This finding is consistent with our earlier works on CBD and CBDA ( Boulebd, 2022a ; Boulebd et al., 2022 ), as well as experimental investigations on phytocannabinoids ( Dawidowicz et al., 2021 ). In comparison, the calculated rate constants of CBN, CBC, and CBF are larger than that of Trolox (1.30 × 105 M 1 s 1 ) ( Vo et al., 2020b ) and BHT (2.51 × 10 5 M 1 s 1 ) ( Boulebd, 2022b ), implying that these phytocannabinoids are effective free radical scavengers under physiologically polar conditions.

To get a more reliable estimation of the antiradical potency of phytocannabinoids, the predicted rate constant of CBF, as the most active derivative in polar physiological environments, was compared to the experimental value of the reference antioxidant Trolox. The molar fraction of the HOO • radical at physiological pH (0.00251), however, must be included in the koverall of CBF to obtain a reliable result as follows: ) k fHAT (CBF) = k appfHAT 9.90 × 10 2 × fCBF(0.9901) × fHOO(0.00251)
k overall = k f (fHAT) + k f (SET2) = 1.32 × 10 4 M 1 s 1

As we can see, the value obtained for CBF (1.32 × 10 4 M 1 s 1 ) is comparable to the experimental value of Trolox (1.70 × 104 M 1 s 1 ) ( Bielski et al., 1985 ), indicating that CBF is a potent scavenger of HOO • in polar physiological environments.

In light of these findings, it can be seen that CBF and CBC are the most effective HOO • scavengers in both environments while being as effective as reference antioxidants Trolox and BHT. This leads us to conclude that CBF and CBC are promising HOO • scavengers in physiological media.

paragraph.emphasis: 2.5. Scavenging potential toward typical free radicals in water

subSection.paragraph: Although the reaction toward HOO • is used as a standard, there is some variation in the radical scavenging reactions with other species. Thus, the antiradical activity of the most promising phytocannabinoid in the aqueous medium (CBF) was also examined against a variety of typical free radicals including peroxyl radicals ( CH 3 COO • and Cl 3 COO • ), hydroxyl radical (HO • ), alkoxy radicals ( CH 3 O • and Cl 3 CO • ), nitrogen dioxide (NO 2 ), nitric oxide (NO), superoxide anion (O 2 • – ), sulfate radical anion (SO 4 • – ), and nitride radical (N • 3 ). This study focused exclusively on the SET mechanism from the anionic form of CBF which is the primary mechanism in water at physiological pH. The obtained rate constants are reported in Table 2 . By analyzing the data in Table 2 , we can conclude that CBF has a moderate inhibition capacity against SO 4 • - ( k f = 1.09 × 103 M 1 s 1 ), but an excellent ability to inhibit CH 3 COO • ( k f = 1.88 × 10 6 M 1 s 1 ) and Cl 3 COO • ( k f = 1.88 × 10 6 M 1 s 1 ) as well as CH 3 O • ( k f = 9.11 × 106 M 1 s 1 ) and NO 2 ( k f = 4.26 × 106 M 1 s 1 ). However, CBF is ineffective for scavenging HO • , NO, and O 2 • - under the conditions examined. The prediction of low activity against HO • implies that SET is not the correct mechanism for this radical; highly reactive radicals are known to follow other routes (fHAT or RAF) that are mainly barrierless in aqueous conditions ( Hieu et al., 2022 ; Hoa et al., 2020 ). These findings corroborate the work of Dawidowicz et al. (2021) , which shows that phytocannabinoid antioxidant activity exceeds that of Trolox when radicals/metal ions are reduced through the SET mechanism by the transfer of electrons from phenolic groups.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 5. Localized TSs for fHAT mechanism of phytocannabinoids in the lipid-like environment. The Distances are in A .

Kinetic data of the reaction of CBF with typical free radicals in water following the SET2 mechanism: activation Gibbs free energies (ΔG = in kcal/mol), nuclear reorganization energy (λ), and rate constants ( k in M 1 s 1 ).

subSection.paragraph: The radical scavenging ability of phytocannabinoids has been systematically assessed using both thermodynamic and kinetic calculations under physiological conditions. In light of these computations, it can be concluded that the antiradical capacity of phytocannabinoids depends on the environment and the structure of the molecule. In the lipid-like environment, phytocannabinoids are relatively moderate to good HOO • scavengers, reacting mainly according to the fHAT mechanism. However, in water at physiological pH, the antiradical properties of phytocannabinoids are substantially better and mainly defined by the SET mechanism from the anionic state, which is in good agreement with the available experimental data. CBN, CBC, and CBF were identified as the most promising molecules in water for scavenging HOO • radical with overall rate constants higher than that of reference compounds Trolox and BHT. Furthermore, CBF exhibited excellent free radical scavenging activity against peroxyl radicals, methoxy radicals, and nitrogen dioxide. These findings may shed new light on how phytocannabinoids exert their antiradical action and inspire the development of novel potential derivatives.
k = σκ kBT e (Δ G =) /RT h

Where σ is the reaction symmetry number (Fern´andez-Ramos et al., 2007; Pollak and Pechukas, 1978 ), κ represents tunneling corrections computed using the Eckart barrier ( Eckart, 1930 ),
kB
is the Boltzmann constant, h is the Planck constant, ΔG = is Gibbs free energy of activation. More details on the methodology are presented in Tables S1 and SI.
